comment.author: 34305619@N06
comment._content: Can't you imagine the rush to get them all indoors at the first hint of rain! Love the two bits immediately above his head!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: 12/6 for a fedora. These days they're about EUR 180. How does that compare, taking inflation into account?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] www.measuringworth.com/ukcompare/ . 12/6 in 1928 is now - £30.80 using the retail price index £32.50 using the GDP deflator £96.30 using the average earnings £148.00 using the per capita GDP £205.00 using the share of GDP [Edited and link fixed]

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: My favourite thing is the "pegs" to straighten the piles of hat boxes against the slope of Barronstrand Street!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: A travelling salesman for hats often stays at our B&B in Blackpool. www.ssphats.net/

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] Another wonderful photo Carol, I think Mr Brennan was in business a bit before my time but shops like these were still around in the 60's when I was a child. This is a photo of my mother taken two doors down from Mr Brennans in the 1950's, she worked across the street in the Savoy Cinema at the time.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: No market for lingerie in the 20's? He's got some pretty nifty hats though...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] Brevity was the sale of lingerie. (with apologies to Dorothy Parker)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] Very definitely a market for lingerie in the 1920s. Here was Mr Brennan's shop in 1926...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Given that hideous Valentine's Day approacheth, here's an antidote from Dorothy Parker also: A single flow’r he sent me, since we met. All tenderly his messenger he chose; Deep-hearted, pure, with scented dew still wet — One perfect rose. I knew the language of the floweret; ‘My fragile leaves,’ it said, ‘his heart enclose.’ Love long has taken for his amulet One perfect rose. Why is it no one ever sent me yet One perfect limousine, do you suppose? Ah no, it’s always just my luck to get One perfect rose.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
